title.text: Book Review Natural Language Processing for Historical Texts

abstractContent.text: The publication of a scholarly book is always the conjunction of an author's desire (or need) to disseminate their experience and knowledge and the interest or expectations of a potential community of readers to gain benefit from the publication itself.

Michael Piotrowski has indeed managed to optimize this relation by bringing to the public a compendium of information that I think has been heavily awaited by many scholars having to deal with corpora of historical texts.
The book covers most topics related to the acquisition, encoding, and annotation of historical textual data, seen from the point of view of their linguistic content.

entities.text: acquisition, encoding, and annotation of historical textual data

abstractContent.text: As such, it does not address issues related, for instance, to scholarly editions of these texts, but conveys a wealth of information on the various aspects where recent developments in language technology may help digital humanities projects to be aware of the current state of the art in the field.
